00001 from node import *

00006 class BackPropTTNetwork:
00007     def __init__(self, input, hidden, output, history, seed=0):
00008         """Create a 3-layer NN that uses backpropagation through time
00009 
00010         input (int) :: number of input nodes
00011         hidden (int) :: number of hidden nodes
00012         output (int) :: number of output nodes
00013         history (int) :: how many times steps to use for backprop
00014         seed (int) :: random number generator see
00015         """
00016 
00017         self.id = -1
00018         self.doprop = False
00019         self.layers = [[], [], []]
00020         self.inputs = []
00021         self.outputs = []
00022         self.tnode = Node("threshold", self.doprop)
00023         self.tnode.outval = 1.0
00024         self.history = history + 1 # The history also includes the current activation
00025         self.oldw = {} # Old weight changes used for momentum
00026 
00027         self.rand = random.Random()
00028         self.rand.seed(seed)
00029         for i in xrange(input):
00030             self.addToInputLayer()
00031         for i in xrange(hidden):
00032             self.addToHiddenLayer(self.rand.uniform(-1.0, 1.0))
00033         for i in xrange(output):
00034             self.addToOutputLayer(self.rand.uniform(-1.0, 1.0))
00035 
00036         # This connects all the hidden node together with recurrent links
00037         for i in self.layers[1]:
00038             for j in self.layers[1]:
00039                 self.addConnection(i, j, self.rand.uniform(-1.0, 1.0), 1)
00040 
00041     def addToInputLayer(self):
00042         """Adds a node to the input layer"""
00043         newnode = self.addNode(0, squash=False)
00044 
00045         # Create a new connection between the network and the input node
00046         conn = Connection(self, newnode, 1.0, self.doprop)
00047         self.inputs.append(conn)
00048         newnode.inputs.append(conn)
00049 
00050     def addToOutputLayer(self, threshold):
00051         """Adds a node to the output layer
00052         
00053         threshold (float) :: the node's threshold weight
00054         """
00055         newnode = self.addNode(2, threshold)
00056 
00057         # Create a new connection between the network and the output node
00058         conn = Connection(newnode, self, 1.0, self.doprop)
00059         self.outputs.append(conn)
00060         newnode.outputs.append(conn)
00061 
00062     def addToHiddenLayer(self, threshold):
00063         """Adds a node to the hidden layer
00064         
00065         threshold (float) :: the node's threshold weight
00066         """
00067         newnode = self.addNode(1, threshold)
00068 
00069     def addNode(self, layer, threshold=None, squash=True):
00070         """Adds a node to the network and adds connections
00071 
00072         layer (int) :: which layer this node belongs, 0 - input, 1 - hidden, 2 - output
00073         threshold (float) :: A node's threshold weight. Optionally none for input nodes
00074 
00075         return newnode (Node) :: the new node created
00076         """
00077         id = (layer, len(self.layers[layer]))
00078         newnode = Node(id, self.doprop, self.history, squash)
00079         self.layers[layer].append(newnode)
00080         if threshold:
00081             self.addThreshold(newnode, threshold)
00082         if layer != 0: # Input nodes don't have predecessor nodes
00083             for n in self.layers[layer-1]:
00084                 self.addConnection(n, newnode, self.rand.uniform(-2.0, 2.0))
00085         if layer != 2: # Output nodes don't have ancesstor nodes
00086             for n in self.layers[layer+1]:
00087                 self.addConnection(newnode, n, self.rand.uniform(-2.0, 2.0))
00088         return newnode
00089 
00090     def addConnection(self, src, dest, weight=1.0, delay=0):
00091         """Adds a connection between two nodes
00092 
00093         src (Node) :: The source node
00094         dest (Node) :: The destination node
00095         weight (float) :: Optional (default 1.0). The weight of this connection
00096         delay (int) :: Optional (default 0). Recurrent links have values greater than 0.
00097                        This is how far back in time it gets its value. Right now this
00098                        has only been tested with values of 0 and 1.
00099         """
00100         conn = Connection(src, dest, weight, self.doprop, delay)
00101         src.outputs.append(conn)
00102         dest.inputs.append(conn)
00103 
00104     def addThreshold(self, dest, threshold):
00105         """Adds a threshold connection to the threshold node
00106 
00107         dest (Node) :: The destination node
00108         theshold (float) :: The weight of the threshold connection
00109         """
00110         conn = Connection(self.tnode, dest, threshold)
00111         self.tnode.outputs.append(conn)
00112         dest.inputs.append(conn)
00113         dest.threshold = self.tnode
00114 
00115     def setInput(self, vals):
00116         """Sets the inputs of the network to vals and propagates the values
00117 
00118         vals (list:float or ints) :: The input values
00119 
00120         Side effects: All the nodes and connections will likely have different
00121         values after this call
00122         
00123         After the values have been propagated, it takes the final activation of the hidden 
00124         nodes and pushes it on to the front of the queue and pops of the last of the
00125         queue. This is and important timing issue. When propagating the values, 
00126         the top of the queue will have the activation from one time step in the
00127         past. When backpropagating errors, the head of the queue will be the same as
00128         the current activation.
00129 
00130         """
00131         if len(vals) != len(self.inputs):
00132             print len(vals), len(self.inputs)
00133             raise InputSizeError # My own custom error! Pointless!
00134 
00135         for i in xrange(len(vals)):
00136             self.inputs[i].setValue(float(vals[i]))
00137 
00138         for layer in self.layers:
00139             for node in layer:
00140                 node.onInput()
00141 
00142         for node in self.layers[1]:
00143             node.history.insert(0, node.outval)
00144             node.history.pop()
00145 
00146     def getOutput(self):
00147         """Returns a list of the output nodes activations"""
00148         vals = []
00149         for o in self.outputs:
00150             vals.append(o.getValue())
00151         return vals
00152 
00153     def test(self, pattern):
00154         """Tests the current network on the test data
00155 
00156         patterns (list or generator) :: It looks like this:
00157             [ 
00158                 [ [list of inputs], [output list] ],
00159                 ...more patterns...
00160             ]
00161             
00162             The generator should return a list (or tuple) of the input and output list:
00163             ([list of inputs], [list of outputs])
00164 
00165             At no point is the list modified, so the whole thing can be nested tuples
00166             if you like. The values of inputs and outputs can be floats or ints.
00167 
00168         returns (right, wrong, kap) (int, int, dict) ::
00169             right - number of correct guesses
00170             wrong - number of wrong guesses
00171             kap - a two dimentional kappa matrix (dictionary). Kappa not actually calulated
00172 
00173         Note: This is a fairly generic test function and may not work in many cases.
00174         For example, all the outputs are rounded to 1.0 or 0.0 which will only work
00175         if your sample outputs should be one or zero. It is easy to make your own
00176         test fuction. Just cycle through your own patterns, call setInput() and 
00177         getOutput() and do whatever calculations you like
00178         """
00179         right = 0
00180         wrong = 0
00181         kap = {}
00182         for p in pattern:
00183             input = p[0]
00184             self.setInput(input)
00185             output = [int(round(v)) for v in self.getOutput()]
00186             if p[1] == output:
00187                 right += 1
00188             else:
00189                 wrong += 1
00190             lt = tuple(p[1])
00191             rt = tuple(output)
00192             if not kap.has_key(lt):
00193                 kap[lt] = {}
00194             if not kap[lt].has_key(rt):
00195                 kap[lt][rt] = 0
00196             kap[lt][rt] += 1
00197         return right, wrong, kap
00198 
00199     def train(self, patgen, rate, mrate, fi=None):
00200         """Trains a network for a given set of patterns
00201 
00202         patgen (Generator generator) :: Alright, let me explain,
00203             I use a generator function to create the set of patterns used in training.
00204             This is because when I created this thing, my test problem was predicting
00205             sine, with which I can easily generate points dynamically through a generator.
00206             The problem with a generator is when it is done generating, there isn't a way to
00207             reset it. Well, I can in python2.5, but 2.4 is still pretty prevalent. So, I need
00208             a way to generate pattern generators. It's kind of messy to explain, but looks
00209             good in code. Just look at the examples.
00210         rate (float) :: Learning rate
00211         mrate (float) :: Momentum rate
00212         fi (File) :: Optional. If specified, the epoch error will be dump to a files. 
00213                      Otherwise it is dumped to stdout.
00214         """
00215         self.epoch = 0
00216         for patterns in patgen:
00217             self.epoch += 1
00218             error = 0.0
00219             self.clear()
00220             self.patnum = 0
00221             for p in patterns:
00222                 input = p[0]
00223                 target = p[1]
00224                 self.setInput(input)
00225 
00226                 # We don't want to start adjusting weights until the history has been filled
00227                 #if self.patnum > self.history:
00228                 error += self.adjustWeights(target, rate, mrate)
00229                 self.patnum += 1
00230             if fi:
00231                 print >> fi, i, error
00232             else:
00233                 print self.epoch, error
00234 
00235     def clear(self):
00236         for node in self.layers[1]:
00237             node.clear()
00238 
00239     def adjustWeights(self, target, rate, mrate):
00240         """Apply backpropagation through time on network and adjust weights
00241 
00242         target (list) :: the list of target outputs
00243         rate (float) :: learning rate
00244         mrate (float) :: momentum rate
00245 
00246         I don't think I can explain how backprop through time works here. There are
00247         papers and books for that. But I can explain my implementation and how it ties
00248         into the damned algorithm. 90% of this is standard backprop. Understanding that
00249         is probably a wise prequisite. I'll be mostly commenting on the "through time"
00250         parts. Read on!
00251         """
00252         outnodes = self.layers[2]
00253         if len(target) != len(outnodes):
00254             raise ValueError("wrong number of target values")
00255 
00256         # The keys are a tuple of the node and the time step for that delta (node, time). 
00257         # time = 0 is for the current time step. time > 0 is for back in time. It would
00258         # make more sense if time decreased, but it makes the programming a little easier.
00259         deltas = {}
00260 
00261         # Calculate output errors. Nothing different here.
00262         for k in xrange(len(target)):
00263             error = target[k] - outnodes[k].outval
00264             deltas[(outnodes[k],0)] = dfunc(outnodes[k].outval) * error
00265         
00266         # Calculate output error for hidden nodes at t = 0. Recurrent links aren't used for
00267         # this calculation. Except for that if statement, this is identical to regular
00268         # backprop. The reason that recurrent links aren't used is because it is important
00269         # to remember that hidden state layer and the hidden past state layer are really
00270         # "different" layers. The deltas at t = 0 only depend on the output layer. The 
00271         # state layer at t = 1 depends on the state layer at t = 0, t = 2 depends on t = 1, 
00272         # and so on. I hope this makes sense. BPTT is really confusing and hard to explain
00273         # without pictures. At least for me.
00274         for node in self.layers[1]:
00275             error = 0.0
00276             for conn in node.outputs:
00277                 if conn.delay == 0:
00278                     error += deltas[(conn.dest, 0)] * conn.weight
00279             deltas[(node,0)] = dfunc(node.outval) * error
00280 
00281         # Now we can calculate deltas for older time steps. Because the t = 0 hidden 
00282         # layer relies on the output layer, unlike the t > 0 hidden layers that depend
00283         # on newer time hidden layers, it had to be calculated seperately. But now that we are
00284         # on the t > 0 hidden, we can iteratively move through the time steps. Notice that
00285         # this is for the most part identical to regular backprop, except now we keep moving
00286         # back in time (by increasing t (or i in this case)), the the dependent layer isn't
00287         # the output layer but hidden layer t - 1.
00288         
00289         # I'm assuming a delay of 1 here at all times. I should make it more general
00290         for i in xrange(self.history-1):
00291             for node in self.layers[1]:
00292                 error = 0.0
00293                 for conn in node.outputs:
00294                     if conn.delay == 1:
00295                         error += deltas[(conn.dest, i)] * conn.weight
00296                 #I think this is right because hist[0] will be the same as node.outval
00297                 #due to the way I store the history
00298                 deltas[(node, i+1)] = dfunc(node.history[i+1]) * error
00299 
00300         # Now we can start changing weights. First the threshold nodes.
00301         for conn in self.tnode.outputs:
00302             change = deltas[(conn.dest,0)] * conn.weight * rate
00303             conn.weight += change
00304             conn.output = conn.weight
00305 
00306         # Now weight changes for the rest of the nodes. The weight changes for the recurrent
00307         # links are summed over each time step.
00308         for layer in self.layers:
00309             for node in layer:
00310                 for conn in node.outputs:
00311                     if conn.dest.id != -1 and conn.src.id != -1:
00312                         if conn.delay == 0:
00313                             change = deltas[(conn.dest,0)] * conn.input * rate
00314                         elif conn.delay == 1:
00315                             change = 0.0
00316                             for i in xrange(self.history-1):
00317                                 change += deltas[(conn.dest, i)] * conn.src.history[i+1] * rate
00318                         conn.weight += change + self.oldw.get(conn, 0.0) * mrate
00319                         self.oldw[conn] = change
00320         
00321         # find error - RMS
00322         error = 0.0
00323         N = len(target)
00324         for k in xrange(len(target)):
00325             error += 1.0/N * (target[k] - outnodes[k].outval)**2.0
00326         error = error ** 0.5
00327         return error

00331     def __init__(self):
00332         print "Input size doesn't match number of network inputs"

00334 class OutputSizeError(Exception):

00336         print "Output size doesn't match number of network outputs"
